title: How Bugs Sapped Twitter’s Ad Capabilities and Drove Prices Lower
text:
Glitches in Twitter Inc. ’s ad-targeting machinery shaved three or more percentage points off the social-media company’s sales growth last quarter by limiting the platform’s ability to precisely target users and weighing down advertising prices as a result.

Prices fell in the third quarter after a period of growth, Twitter Chief Financial Officer Ned Segal said during an earnings call Thursday to discuss the latest results.

The damage may get worse: Twitter executives said the company is still working to fix the problems, which will reduce fourth-quarter revenue growth by at least 4 percentage points. The problems may also continue into next year, Mr. Segal said.

Twitter called out two bugs that directly affected its ability to target users for advertisers and share crucial data back to measurement partners and advertisers.

The first bug showed some users ads based partly on inferences it made about the types of devices they were using, even if they had opted out of that type of tracking.

The second, revolving around a suite of ad products that help marketers promote their mobile apps on Twitter, shared user data such as country codes with measurement and advertising partners, even if users had not given Twitter permission to do so.

“We’ve been transparent with our partners about the technical issues we have faced with [mobile app promotion], an important area for us,” said a Twitter spokeswoman. “We’re working to increase stability, performance and scale of the product for the long term.”

Twitter disclosed both problems in August.

When Twitter discovered the issues, it turned off the targeting and data-sharing in question, Mr. Segal said.

That hurt Twitter’s earnings potential because advertisers pay higher rates for more precise ad targeting and measurement.

“That’s a necessary cut that they had to make,” said Kait Boulos, vice president of marketing at MDC Partners Inc.-owned ad agency Varick. “In the short term, it’s going to hurt their revenue, but in the long term, it’s the right decision to protect the long-term sustainability of the product and relationship with users.”

But several advertisers said they had not shifted ad spend away from Twitter during the third quarter and said the fact that these previously disclosed product bugs affected revenue growth came as a surprise.

“This is a niche problem that might have impacted a few advertisers, but it’s not something that was brought up to us on a daily basis over the last two months,” said Jordan Jacobson, vice president and head of social media for ad agency iProspect.

“We have followed up with Twitter to get more clarity,” he added. “We want to make sure that everything we did run was correctly targeted.”

Twitter reported $824 million in revenue in the third quarter, up 9% over the year-earlier period, of which $702 million came from advertising, up 8%.

Twitter’s revenue growth in the quarter also suffered from fewer big events and launches than a year earlier, Mr. Segal said.

description: Glitches in Twitter’s ad-targeting machinery shaved three or more percentage points off the social-media company’s sales growth last quarter by limiting the platform’s ability to precisely target users and weighing down ad prices as a result.
